Award.AwardTitle: Electrocatalysis on Structure Controlled Metal Nanocrystals: Unraveling Particle Structure-Catalytic Activity Relationships
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division, Professor Shouzhong Zou of Miami University will carry out studies of the relationships between nanocrystal structure and catalytic activity. Dr. Zou and his students will study electrocatalytic activity of shape, size and composition controlled platinum and platinum-based alloy nanocrystals towards reactions of importance in low temperature fuel cells, using a combination of conventional electrochemical methods, surface vibration spectroscopy, and single particle electrochemistry. Fundamental insights of catalyst structure-activity relationships gained from these studies will aid in rational design and development of highly active and durable fuel cell catalysts, and breaking the bottlenecks in the development and deployment of low temperature fuel cells.

One of the key technical challenges in fuel cell development and commercialization is to find low-cost, highly-efficient catalysts having a long lifetime. By identifying the structural factors dictating the catalytic activity of nanoscale catalysts toward fuel cell reactions, the proposed research directly addresses this pressing issue and will make significant advances in energy conversion in fuel cells. The concepts developed in this research will be applicable to other important structure sensitive reactions as well. In addition this research program will train postdoctoral researchers, graduate students and undergraduate students in electrocatalysis and fuel cells, and will also provide outreach to high schools through a teacher-researcher program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A grand challenge in contemporary heterogeneous catalysis is to identify the structure of catalytic active sites so that rational design of low cost catalysts with high catalytic activity, selectivity, and long durability can be realized. Because of the complexity of practical catalysts, single crystal surfaces with well-defined structures have been employed as model catalysts to understand how the surface atomic arrangements of a catalyst determine its catalytic activity. These studies have tremendously advanced our understanding of surface adsorption, reaction and other processes. A limitation of this approach, however, lies in that the catalysts used in practice are often nanoparticles, and the knowledge obtained on large millimeter size single crystal surfaces often cannot be extrapolated to practical catalysts. To close this “size gap”, it is highly desirable to directly study the particle structure and reactivity relationships. Unfortunately, many studies of the particle reactivity have only come to controversial conclusions due to the lack of control in particle structure. In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, the PI and his group studied electrocatalytic activities of size, shape (i.e. surface atomic arrangement), and composition controlled Pt-group metal nanocrystal catalysts toward oxygen reduction, as well as carbon monoxide, methanol, and formic acid oxidation, which are of direct relevance to low temperature fuel cells. The first step to conduct meaningful catalytic activity study is to make sure the catalyst surface is cleaned. A simple electrochemical method for removing surfactants from Pt nanocubes was developed. These surfactants were introduced in the particle synthesis to control the size and shape of the particles.  This approach has since been extended to cleaning other nanocrystals for electrocatalysis studies. Bu using shape controlled Pt3M (M=Mn, Fe, Co and Ni) nanocubes with a similar size, the effects of alloyed elements on oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activities were explored. It was found that the activity vs the d-band center of the alloying metal followed a volcano plot. Pd nanorods with a fixed width but varying length from 100 to 500 nm were synthesized by a new one pot approach and their catalytic activities for formic acid oxidation were found to increase with decreasing rod length. Au and Pd nanocrystals with different exposed facets have been synthesized and applications of these nanocrystals to surface-enhanced Raman and electrocatalysis have been explored.

Broader impacts of this research relate to its development of new strategies for synthesizing shape controlled particles with varying dimension. The results from the catalytic activity studies will contribute to the broad knowledge base for developing new fuel cell catalysts and other energy technologies such as lithium batteries. Furthermore, the proposed research has trained young scientists working in the STEM fields. Three postdocs, four PhD and one MS students were trained and some of them went on to work in various energy related industries and academic institutions. Among them two are female students and one from underrepresented groups. To further broaden the impact of this research and disseminate the gained knowledge, the PI and his group also worked with a high school teacher on metal nanocrystal synthesis and the use of these nanocrystals in fuel cell related research. Based on this research experience, the teacher developed some course materials to be used in high school classrooms.
